trade.title: Trade
keyTrends: Plastic imports have grown rapidly between 2012 and 2018, while exports remained extremely small, confirming that the {{country}} are a strong net importer of plastics.
Imports are dominated by finished plastic products rather than raw materials, indicating limited domestic capacity for plastic manufacturing and conversion.
The plastic economy is highly import-dependent and Asia-centric, with ~75% of plastic imports originating from Asia.
Plastic packaging and consumer-related products dominate trade, with the largest imported plastic categories including plastic packaging and closures, worn clothing, pipes, hoses, and fittings.

Plastic consumption was reported to be rising sharply, particularly after 2015, reinforcing the link between increasing plastic flows, limited re-export capacity for recycling, and escalating pressure on domestic waste management systems.
trade.summaryLeft:
Plastic Imports

A total of 88,381 thousand USD worth of plastic was imported to {{country}} between 2012-2018. In the latest reporting year 2018, the total imports reached value of 21,700 thousand USD, of which:

  • ~ 6% was plastic in primary forms
  • ~ 8% was plastic in intermediate forms
  • ~ 18% was intermediate manufactured plastic goods
  • ~ 67% was final manufactured plastic goods
  • ~ 0% was plastic waste.

Plastic exports

A total of 113 thousand USD worth of plastic was exported from {{country}} in the year(s) 2012-2018. In the latest reporting year 2018, exports reached a value of USD 51 thousand, of which:

  • ~ 84% was plastic in primary forms
  • ~ 0% was plastic in intermediate forms
  • ~ 10% was intermediate manufactured plastic goods
  • ~ 6% was final manufactured plastic goods
  • ~ 773% was plastic waste.
trade.summary:
Plastic trade trends

Between years 2017 and 2018, the amount of plastic imported to {{country}} has increased by 13.3%, while the amount of plastic exported from {{country}} has remained extremely small.

The value of total plastic imports more than tripled between 2012 and 2018, from 6.3 million USD to 21.7 million USD. Imports are dominated by final manufactured goods, which accounted for approximately 67% of total plastic imports in 2018, compared with intermediate goods (18%), intermediate forms (8%), and primary polymers (6%). This indicates that the economy primarily imports finished plastic products rather than polymers for local-scale manufacturing. However, primary and intermediate import forms of plastic have increased from near-zero pre-2015 to a combined value of over USD 3 million, suggesting either improved reporting and/or growing demand for packaging/material inputs, yet still far smaller than finished goods.

{{country}} is a strong net importer of plastics, with exports amounting to approximately USD 0.05 million in 2018. Waste exports are evident only in 2018, with a reported value of USD 0.39 million.
trade.tradingPartners: The {{country}}’ plastic economy is import-dependent and Asia-centric (~75%), with regional (Oceania) suppliers playing a secondary role (~23%). The economy has no significant export footprint. This reinforces the conclusion that plastics enter the economy primarily as finished products, with limited domestic conversion or re-export.
trade.productCategories: The World Trade Organisation’s database can provide more in-depth insights into specific products. {{country}} predominantly imports items categorised under plastics and articles thereof (HS Chapter 39). The top import items in this category include plastic packaging and tubes, pipes, hoses, and fittings, which account for USD 7.6 million. Exports are much smaller, consisting of synthetic resins and polymers in primary form (USD 0.04 million). The second product category that dominates {{country}}’ plastic imports is textiles, apparel and footwear (HS chapters 54-65), particularly second-hand clothing, accounting for over 3.8 million USD. Top exports include sacks and bags for packing goods, men’s/boys’ knitted shirts, and tarpaulins/awnings/tents. The third product category is rubber (HS Chapter 40), for which the largest import categories are new pneumatic tyres, used tyres, and inner rubber tubes. Exports are extremely limited, consisting almost entirely of new tyres and vulcanised rubber articles.

consumption.title: Consumption
consumption.content: Plastic consumption is calculated as total imports minus exports, using UNCTAD data. These data indicate an increasing trend in plastic consumption in {{country}}, particularly since 2015.

wasteManagement.title: Waste Management
keyTrends: Plastic waste is rising rapidly, driven almost entirely by imported consumer goods and packaging, particularly food-related flexible packaging, sachets, PET bottles, thin bags, and disposable nappies.
Formal waste collection and management are highly uneven. In peri-urban and rural areas, uncollected waste is commonly burned, dumped, buried or littered.
Landfilling predominates in formal disposal, whereas recycling infrastructure is limited to niche, small-scale initiatives.
wasteManagement.content:
Plastic waste from municipal solid waste

An estimated 212 thousand tonnes of municipal solid waste were generated in {{country}} in 2020, with an estimated 0.83 - 0.86 kg per person per day, of which 17% is plastic.

A study on global waste management modeling showed 41% of municipal solid waste is collection coverage, with annual plastic emission including both debris and open burning is 8,956 tonnes per year, which is equivalent to 13 kg/person/year.

The estimated MSW generation per capita in {{country}} in 2020 was 0.84 kg per person per day.

Waste collection in urban areas is largely limited to mixed waste, with no systematic segregation or material recovery, whereas on the urban fringes and in rural areas, the absence of formal waste management systems leads to widespread open burning, dumping, and littering. Recycling rates remain extremely low and are largely confined to informal or pilot-scale activities. Three local businesses provide niche solutions: plastic collection for reuse and waste-to-energy pyrolysis, upcycling into handicrafts, and eco-plastic bricks.

Primary data collection through a waste composition survey undertaken recorded that the share of plastic waste within the collected waste was 16% in Honiara in 2025, disposable nappies alone accounting for up to 6%. The same primary data collection estimated that the per capita MSW generation in Honiara was 0.93 kg per person per day.
wasteManagement.contentRight:
Plastic waste from non-municipal solid waste

There is no data on plastic waste from non-municipal solid waste in {{country}}.

environment.title: Plastics in the Environment
keyTrends: Plastic pollution is dominated by short-lived consumer packaging, particularly food-related flexible packaging and PET bottles.
Leakage pathways are widespread, including dumping, open burning, burying, and littering, especially outside urban centres.
Rivers are a major conduit for plastic pollution, with plastics comprising over half of reported riverine debris.
environment.content:
Beach litter

It is estimated that 56 tonnes of plastic per day enter the marine environment, with plastics accounting for half of the litter in rivers, highlighting rivers as a major pathway for plastic leakage.

Common plastic items in the environment

According to a waste audit in 2025, the ten most common plastic waste generated is retail food flexible packaging, sachets, retail PET bottles, produce thin bags, plastic snacks packaging, retail bottle plastic lids, disposable nappies, fragmented plastics, other plastics and other plastic lids. These items are lightweight, short-lived, and highly prone to leakage, particularly under conditions of informal disposal and open-burning.

The dominance of flexible packaging and sachets suggests that weight-based indicators alone may underrepresent environmental risk, as these items contribute disproportionately to leakage despite their low mass.

lifeCycleInsights.title: Life Cycle Insights
keyTrends: {{country}} is a strong net importer of plastics with virtually no domestic production or significant exports, meaning nearly all plastics entering the economy remain in-country.
Plastic imports more than tripled from 6.3 million USD in 2012 to 21.7 million USD in 2018, dominated by finished consumer goods and packaging.
Plastic consumption has risen sharply, particularly since 2015, reinforcing growing pressure on waste management systems.
Only 41% of municipal solid waste is collected, with annual plastic emissions of 8,956 tonnes (13 kg/person/year), and recycling infrastructure remains limited to niche initiatives.
An estimated 56 tonnes of plastic per day enter the marine environment, with rivers as a major pathway and flexible packaging as the dominant waste type.
lifeCycleInsights.content:
{{country}} is entirely import-dependent for plastics. There is no domestic plastic production. The economy relies entirely on imported finished products, packaging, and consumer goods. Total plastic imports more than tripled from 6.3 million USD in 2012 to 21.7 million USD in 2018, with final manufactured goods accounting for 67% of imports. Asia supplies approximately 75% of all plastic imports, with Oceania providing about 23%.

Plastic consumption is rising sharply. With virtually no exports, nearly all imported plastics remain in the economy. Consumption has increased particularly rapidly since 2015, driven by growing demand for packaged consumer goods. This rising flow of plastics into the economy, combined with limited re-export or recycling capacity, directly increases pressure on domestic waste management systems.

Waste management capacity is severely limited. An estimated 212 thousand tonnes of MSW were generated in 2020, with only 41% collection coverage. Annual plastic emissions including debris and open burning reach 8,956 tonnes (13 kg/person/year). Outside urban areas, waste is commonly burned, dumped, buried, or littered. Recycling is confined to niche, small-scale initiatives.

Plastic pollution is pervasive in the environment. An estimated 56 tonnes of plastic enter the marine environment daily, with rivers serving as a major pathway. Flexible food packaging, sachets, PET bottles, and thin bags dominate the waste stream. The lightweight nature of these items means they contribute disproportionately to environmental leakage despite their low mass.
